trans-unit.source: bresenham : Bresenham method (default) andres : Andres method
computing the gradient image in row and col
create_connection id1, id2, pos1, pos2, cost1, cost2)

deltaE_ciede94 is not symmetric with respect to lab1 and lab2. CIEDE94 defines the scales for the lightness, hue, and chroma in terms of the first color. Consequently, the first color should be regarded as the “reference” color.
deltaE_cmc the defines the scales for the lightness, hue, and chroma in terms of the first color. Consequently deltaE_cmc(lab1, lab2) != deltaE_cmc(lab2, lab1)
dtype for return value (sane choices: float32 or float64).
finer quantization of the angular space which is gray scale and rotation invariant.
floats: subtract the image from 1 (if signed_float is False, so we assume the image is unsigned), or from 0 (if signed_float is True).
if True, normalize covariances by N-1 rather than, N where N is the number of pixels within the sliding window.
image texture which is rotation but not gray scale invariant.
inner: outline the pixels just inside of objects, leaving background pixels untouched.
int goal_reached(int index, float cumcost) This method is called each iteration after popping an index from the heap, before examining the neighbours.
lightness scale factor, 1 for “acceptably close”; 2 for “imperceptible” see deltaE_cmc
local variance at each point of image
n is uniform noise with specified mean & variance.
n-d index into array defining the end point
n-d index into array defining the starting point
offset of the connectivity (one offset per dimension)
on a Plugin instance. The Plugin will delegate action based on the widget’s parameter type specified by its ptype attribute, which can be:
or, to translate x by 10 and y by 20:
outer: outline pixels in the background around object boundaries. When two objects touch, their boundary is also marked.
random walker segmentation A segmentation algorithm based on anisotropic diffusion, usually slower than the watershed but with good results on noisy data and boundaries with holes.
s1 and s2 are label fields of the same shape.
segmentdata argument is a dictionary with a red, green and blue entries. Each entry should be a list of x, y0, y1 tuples, forming rows in a table. Entries for alpha are optional.
shift structuring element about center point. This only affects eccentric structuring elements (i.e. selem with even numbered sides).
sigma for the Gaussian when gaussian_weights is True.
signed integers: subtract the image from -1 (see Notes)
subpixel: return a doubled image, with pixels between the original pixels marked as boundary where appropriate.

the dimensions of the input image and N is n_bins or image.max() + 1 if no value is provided as a parameter. Effectively, each pixel is a N-D feature vector that is the histogram. The sum of the elements in the feature vector will be 1, unless no pixels in the window were covered by both selem and mask, in which case all elements will be 0.
the starting level set is defined as sin(x/5*pi)*sin(y/5*pi), where x and y are pixel coordinates. This level set has fast convergence, but may fail to detect implicit edges.
the starting level set is defined as the opposite of the distance from the center of the image minus a quarter of the minimum value between image width and image height.

the starting level set is defined as the opposite of the distance from the center of the image minus half of the minimum value between image width and image height. This is somewhat slower, but is more likely to properly detect implicit edges.
thick: any pixel not completely surrounded by pixels of the same label (defined by connectivity) is marked as a boundary. This results in boundaries that are 2 pixels thick.
tolerance to achieve when solving the linear system, in cg’ and ‘cg_mg’ modes.
unsigned integers: subtract the image from the dtype maximum
watershed segmentation A segmentation algorithm based on mathematical morphology and “flooding” of regions from markers.
where (xt, yt) is the closest point on the ellipse to (x, y). Thus d is the shortest distance from the point to the ellipse.
where m_00 is the zeroth spatial moment.
where s is a scale factor and the homogeneous transformation matrix is:
where success indicates whether the model estimation succeeded (True or None for success, False for failure).
where sx and sy are scale factors in the x and y directions, and the homogeneous transformation matrix is:
where wm_00 is the zeroth spatial moment (intensity-weighted area).

where \(F\) and \(F^\dagger\) are the Fourier and inverse Fourier transfroms respectively, \(\Lambda_H\) the transfer function (or the Fourier transfrom of the PSF, see [Hunt] below) and \(\Lambda_D\) the filter to penalize the restored image frequencies (Laplacian by default, that is penalization of high frequency). The parameter \(\lambda\) tunes the balance between the data (that tends to increase high frequency, even those coming from noise), and the regularization.
where \(n\) is noise, \(H\) the PSF and \(x\) the unknown original image, the Wiener filter is

where m(x,y) and s(x,y) are the mean and standard deviation of pixel (x,y) neighborhood defined by a rectangular window with size w times w centered around the pixel. k is a configurable parameter that weights the effect of standard deviation.

where m(x,y) and s(x,y) are the mean and standard deviation of pixel (x,y) neighborhood defined by a rectangular window with size w times w centered around the pixel. k is a configurable parameter that weights the effect of standard deviation. R is the maximum standard deviation of a greyscale image.
where the ‘*’ patch will be determined by the fill parameter.
where the homogeneous transformation matrix is:
where the probability (confidence) is typically set to a high value such as 0.99, and e is the current fraction of inliers w.r.t. the total number of samples.
where the sum is over the x, y coordinates of the region, and x_c and y_c are the coordinates of the region’s centroid.
where the sum is over the x, y coordinates of the region, and x_c and y_c are the coordinates of the region’s weighted centroid.
where the sum is over the x, y coordinates of the region.
where x_m = 1 on markers of the given phase, and 0 on other markers. This linear system is solved in the algorithm using a direct method for small images, and an iterative method for larger images.
where || . || denotes the Frobenius norm and N = im_true.size. This result is equivalent to:
which exist for each set of corresponding points, so we have a set of N * 2 equations. The coefficients appear linearly so we can write A x = 0, where:
which is approximated by the weighted sum of squared differences in a local window around each pixel in the image.
which is computed by convolving the image with the second derivatives of the Gaussian kernel in the respective x- and y-directions.
which is only gray scale invariant [2].
with first indices corresponding to marked pixels, and then to unmarked pixels, minimizing x.T L x for one phase amount to solving:
